intro: Frumentum sylvaticum, commonly known as wild millet, is a herbaceous annual plant native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm and has alternate, lanceolate leaves with hairy surfaces. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers arranged in spikelets, which are clustered in panicles. Its seeds are small, oval, and often used as a grain in traditional agriculture. Frumentum sylvaticum is adapted to disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of habitats, including fields and woodland edges.
